definitions.definition: a table or small shop with an open front that people sell things from, especially at a market

examples.text: He works on a **market stall** in the Square.
They have a fish stall on the market.
Drinks were being sold from makeshift stalls at the side of the road.
He has a flower stall in the market.
I bought this trout at the market fish stall.
Who's going to man the stall at lunchtime?
They have a flower stall at the market.

definitions.definition: a section inside a farm building that is large enough for one animal to be kept in

examples.text: We had to muck out stalls and groom the horses.

definitions.definition: a small area in a room, surrounded by glass, walls, etc., that contains a shower or toilet
the seats that are nearest to the stage in a theatre

examples.text: the front row of the stalls

definitions.definition: the seats at the front of a church where the choir (= singers) and priests sit
a situation in which a vehicle’s engine suddenly stops because it is not getting enough power
a situation in which an aircraft loses speed and goes steeply downwards

examples.text: The plane went into a stall.

wordOrigin: Old English steall ‘stable or cattle shed’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch stal, also to stand. Early senses of the verb included ‘reside, dwell’ and ‘bring to a halt’.
